(3) Does API Quality Matter?



Why Linting? Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(4) It Depends!

  • Quality is in the eye of the consumer
  • Quality is determined by a number of factors
    • Consumer profile: Private, partner, public
    • Number of consumers: One, dozens, thousands
    • Context: Solitary or part of an API landscape
    • Exposed Service: Data, Transaction, Events
    • Lifecycle: early, stable, established
    • Tooling: Support for certain features


Why Linting? Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(10) Minimal Spectral



Using and Tweaking Rules Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(11) No Onions and Extra Cheese, Please!

  • Spectral has a large set of built-in rules for OpenAPI [https://docs.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/4dec24461f3af-open-api-rules]
    • Spectral also has built-in rules for AsyncAPI [https://docs.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/1e63ffd0220f3-async-api-rules] and Arazzo [https://docs.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/96c7245b504b1-arazzo-rules]
  • Rules in rulesets can be selectively tweaked or turned off [https://docs.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/83527ef2dd8c0-extending-rulesets#change-rule-severity]
extends: 
  - spectral:oas
  - spectral:asyncapi
  - spectral:arazzo
rules:
  info-contact: off
  info-description: error
  • ruleset-tweaking-rules.yaml


Using and Tweaking Rules Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

  • Rulesets that (try to) help with standards conformance

(16) My First Rule 

rules:
  info-contact:
    given: $
    then:
      field: info.contact
      function: truthy
  • ruleset-info-contact.yaml
  • Rules have identifiers
  • Rules are applied to parts given with a JSONPath
  • If a given part is found then functions are applied


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(17) JSONPath Online Evaluator



Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(18) JSONPath Basics

  • $: The root object/element
  • @: The current object/element
  • .: Dot-notation to access properties
  • []: Bracket-notation to access array elements


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(19) The Anatomy of a Rule

  • given (required): The part of the document the rule should be applied to (JSONPath)
  • then (required): Describes which function should be applied to the given part of the document
  • description (optional): A short description of the rule
  • message (optional): A message that's displayed in the spectral lint output
  • severity (optional): The severity of the rule
  • formats (optional): The format that the rule should apply to
  • recommended (optional): Users can enforce all rules or only recommended rules
  • resolved (optional): Used to apply a rule to a document that's not resolved


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(20) Linting 204 Responses

  • 204 responses should never carry content 
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Expected response to a valid request
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                $ref: '#/components/schemas/Pet'
        '204':
          description: Response to a soft-deleted resource
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                $ref: '#/components/schemas/Pet'
  • petstore-content-on-204.oas.yaml (line 76-88)


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(21) Linting 204 Responses with a Rule 

extends:
  - spectral:oas
rules:
  no-content-on-204:
    description: "Responses with status code 204 must not contain a content property"
    severity: error
    given: "$.paths.*.*.responses.204"
    then:
      field: content
      function: falsy
  • ruleset-no-content-on-204.yaml


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(22) Linting 204 Responses with a Function

  • Spectral rules span across rules and functions
extends:
  - spectral:oas
functions:
  - ./no-content-on-204
rules:
  no-content-on-204:
    description: "Responses with status code 204 must not contain a content property"
    severity: error
    given: "$.paths.*.*.responses.204"
    then:
      function: no-content-on-204
  • ruleset-no-content-on-204-function.yaml
module.exports = function (targetVal, opts, paths) {
  if (typeof targetVal === "object" && "content" in targetVal) {
    return [
      {
        message: "Responses with status code 204 must not have a content property."
      }
    ];
  }
  return [];
};
  • no-content-on-204.js


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(23) Testing Rules

  • Testing rules helps with making sure they work as expected
  • Creating minimal example helps with better understanding the tests
  • Work your way down from a minimal OpenAPI for creating tests
openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Minimal OpenAPI
  version: 1.0.0
paths: {}
  • minimal-openapi.yaml


Custom Rulesets and Functions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(24) Reusing JSONPath: Aliases 

aliases:
  PathItemObject:
    - $.paths[*]
  OperationObject:
    - "#PathItemObject[get,put,post,delete,options,head,patch,trace]"
  ParameterObject:
    description: Selecting parameters in paths and operations in OAS2 and OAS3
    targets:
      - formats:
          - oas2
        given:
          - "#PathItemObject.parameters[*]"
          - "#OperationObject.parameters[*]"
          - $.parameters[*]
      - formats:
          - oas3
        given:
          - "#PathItemObject.parameters[*]"
          - "#OperationObject.parameters[*]"
          - $.components.parameters[*]
  • aliases.yaml

(26) API Guidelines

  • Depending on intended consumer groups (private/partner/public)
  • Depending on solitary or landscape APIs
  • Depending on API lifecycle stage
  • Depending on sensitivity for specific tooling

Automating Spectral Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(30) Spectral Usage Patterns

  • CLI can be used to manually check (early) designs
  • Integrate Spectral into the IDE of your choice
  • Git hooks [Git Hook: .git/hooks/ (1)] allow API linting to avoid committing problematic files
  • GitHub actions [GitHub Action: .github/workflows (1)] can reject pull requests containing problematic files


Automating Spectral Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(31) Git Hook: .git/hooks/

#!/bin/bash

# Find all staged .oas.yaml and .oas.json files
FILES=$(git diff --cached --name-only --diff-filter=ACM | grep -E '\.oas\.(yaml|json)$')

# If no OpenAPI files are found, exit successfully
if [[ -z "$FILES" ]]; then
  echo "‚úÖ No OpenAPI files staged for commit. Skipping Spectral lint."
  exit 0
fi

# Run Spectral Lint on each staged file
echo "üîç Running Spectral lint..."
ERRORS=0

for FILE in $FILES; do
  npx spectral lint "$FILE" --ruleset ruleset-builtin.yaml
  if [[ $? -ne 0 ]]; then
    ERRORS=1
  fi
done

# If errors were found, block the commit
if [[ $ERRORS -ne 0 ]]; then
  echo "‚ùå Spectral linting failed. Fix issues before committing."
  exit 1
fi

echo "‚úÖ Spectral lint passed! Proceeding with commit."
exit 0
  • pre-commit.sh


Automating Spectral Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(32) GitHub Action: .github/workflows



Automating Spectral Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(33) GitHub Action Workflow 

name: Spectral Linter

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [main, develop]
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  lint:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout Repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Install Spectral
        run: npm install -g @stoplight/spectral-cli

      - name: Find and Lint OpenAPI Files
        run: |
          FILES=$(find . -type f \( -name "*.oas.yaml" -o -name "*.oas.json" \))
          if [[ -z "$FILES" ]]; then
            echo "No OpenAPI files found. Skipping lint."
            exit 0
          fi
          spectral lint $FILES --ruleset ruleset-builtin.yaml || exit 1
  • workflow-spectral.yaml

(35) Platform Engineering

  • Scaling software development is a popular concern
  • Support developers by shifting things down [https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/application-development/richard-seroter-on-shifting-down-vs-shifting-left] for them
  • Helping with API design helps developers with creating better components
  • Helping with API design helps developers to more easily consume components


Conclusions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!

(36) API Design Matters

  • Better API design helps API consumers
  • Spectral helps with improving API quality
  • Spectral provides built-in support for various formats
  • Various rulesets for API guidelines are openly available
  • Advanced users can start writing their own rulesets


Conclusions Erik Wilde: Linting API Descriptions: Consistency is King for Developer Experience!
